sen.j: 中山 忠能（なかやま ただやす、文化 (元号)6年11月11日 (旧暦)（1809年12月17日） - 明治21年（1888年）6月12日）は、江戸時代末期から明治時代前期にかけての公家、政治家である。
sen.e: Tadayasu NAKAYAMA (December 17, 1809-June 12, 1888) was kuge (court noble) and a politician who lived from the end of the Edo period to the early part of the Meiji period.
Tadayasu NAKAYAMA (December 17, 1809-June 12, 1888) was a kuge (court noble) and a politician who lived from the end of the Edo period to the early part of the Meiji period.
Tadayasu NAKAYAMA (December 17, 1809-June 12, 1888) was a kuge (court noble) and a politician who lived from the end of the Edo period to the early part of the Meiji period.

sen.j: 明治政府の議定。
sen.e: He worked as gijo (official post) of the Meiji Government.
He worked as gijo (official post) of the Meiji Government.
He worked as gijo (official post) of the Meiji Government.

sen.j: 父は藤原北家の花山院流大納言・中山忠頼の長男、母は正親町三条実同の娘・綱子。
sen.e: His father was the eldest son of Dainagon (Major Counselor) Tadayori NAKAYAMA (中山忠頼) who was Kazanin line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and his mother was Tsunako, a daughter of Sanetomo OGIMACHISANJO.
sen.cmt: 中山忠頼の読み方不明です。
sen.e: His father was the eldest son of Dainagon (Major Counselor) Tadayori NAKAYAMA (中山忠頼) who was in the Kazanin line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and his mother was Tsunako, a daughter of Sanetomo OGIMACHISANJO.

His father was the eldest son of Dainagon (Major Counselor) Tadayori NAKAYAMA (中山忠頼) who was in the Kazanin line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and his mother was Tsunako, a daughter of Sanetomo OGIMACHISANJO.

sen.j: 子に中山忠光。
sen.e: Tadamitsu NAKAYAMA was his son.
Tadamitsu NAKAYAMA was his son.
Tadamitsu NAKAYAMA was his son.

sen.j: 娘の中山慶子が孝明天皇の典侍で、明治天皇を産んだことから、忠能は明治天皇の外戚に当たる。
sen.e: His daughter Yoshiko NAKAYAMA was Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank) of the Emperor Komei and delivered the Emperor Meiji, so that Tadayasu was a maternal relative of the Emperor Meiji.
His daughter Yoshiko NAKAYAMA was Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank) of the Emperor Komei and delivered the Emperor Meiji, so that Tadayasu was a maternal relative of the Emperor Meiji.
His daughter Yoshiko NAKAYAMA was Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank) of the Emperor Komei and delivered the Emperor Meiji, so that Tadayasu was a maternal relative of the Emperor Meiji.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 弘化4年（1847年）、大納言となる。
sen.e: In 1847 he was assigned to Dainagon.
In 1847 he was assigned to Dainagon.
In 1847 he was assigned to Dainagon.

sen.j: 嘉永6年（1853年）にアメリカ合衆国のマシュー・ペリーが来航して通商を求めた際には攘夷論を主張し、条約締結を巡り、関白の九条尚忠を批判する。
sen.e: When Matthew Perry of the U.S. came to Japan and required to begin commerce in 1853, he insisted the principle of excluding foreigners and criticized Hisatada KUJO, a chief adviser to the Emperor, over the conclusion of treaty.

When Matthew Perry of the U.S. came to Japan and demanded the beginning of trade 1853, he insisted on the principle of excluding foreigners and criticized Hisatada KUJO, a chief adviser to the Emperor, over the conclusion of the treaty.

When Matthew Perry of the U.S. came to Japan and demanded the beginning of trade 1853, he insisted on the principle of excluding foreigners and criticized Hisatada KUJO, a chief adviser to the Emperor, over the conclusion of the treaty.

sen.j: 安政5年（1858年）、江戸幕府老中の堀田正睦が上洛して条約の勅許による許可を求めた際には、正親町三条実愛らと共にこれに反対した。
sen.e: When Masayoshi HOTTA, roju (member of shogun's council of elders) of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), came up to Kyoto in 1858 and required the Imperial permission of the treaty in 1858, he opposed this with Sanenaru OGIMACHISANJO and so on.

When Masayoshi HOTTA, roju (member of a shogun's council of elders) of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), came up to Kyoto in 1858 and required the Imperial permission of the treaty in 1858, he opposed this with Sanenaru OGIMACHISANJO and others.
sen.cmt: Wording. This is a bit convoluted.
sen.e: When Masayoshi HOTTA, roju (member of a shogun's council of elders) of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), came up to Kyoto in 1858 and required the Imperial permission of the treaty in 1858, he opposed this with Sanenaru OGIMACHISANJO and others.

sen.j: その後、議奏となる。
sen.e: After that, he was assigned to giso (a position conveying what the congress decides to the emperor).
After that, he was assigned to giso (a position conveying what the congress decides to the emperor).
After that, he was assigned to giso (a position conveying what the congress decides to the emperor).

sen.j: 公武合体派の公家として万延元年（1860年）、孝明天皇から和宮親子内親王と14代将軍徳川家茂の縁組の御用掛に任じられた。
sen.e: In 1860 he was assigned to Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for the marriage between the Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako and the 14th Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA by the Emperor Komei as the kuge of kobu-gattai (integration of the imperial court and the shogunate) group.

In 1860 he was assigned to Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for the marriage between the Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako and the 14th Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA by the Emperor Komei as the kuge of kobu-gattai (integration of the imperial court and the shogunate) group.

In 1860 he was assigned to Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for the marriage between the Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako and the 14th Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA by the Emperor Komei as the kuge of kobu-gattai (integration of the imperial court and the shogunate) group.

sen.j: その経緯から翌文久元年（1861年）、和宮の江戸下向に随行するが、これが一部の過激な尊皇攘夷派からの憤激を生んだ。
sen.e: By that process, he accompanied Kazunomiya on going down to Edo in the following year, 1861, which made a part of radical Sonno Joi ha (supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor and expelling the barbarians) get angry.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He thereby accompanied Kazunomiya on the journey down to Edo in the following year, 1861, which angered a section of radical Sonno Joi ha (supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor and expelling the barbarians).

He thereby accompanied Kazunomiya on the journey down to Edo in the following year, 1861, which angered a section of radical Sonno Joi ha (supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor and expelling the barbarians).

sen.j: 63年に議奏を辞職して失脚した。
sen.e: In 1863 he resigned giso and fell from power.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1863 he resigned as giso and fell from power.
In 1863 he resigned as giso and fell from power.

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）、長州藩が京都奪還のため挙兵した禁門の変では長州藩の動きを支持した。
sen.e: At the time of the Kinmon Incident in which the Choshu clan rose an army in order to regain Kyoto in 1864, he supported the movement of the Choshu clan.
At the time of the Kinmon Incident in which the Choshu clan raised an army in order to regain Kyoto in 1864, he supported the movement of the Choshu clan.
At the time of the Kinmon Incident in which the Choshu clan raised an army in order to regain Kyoto in 1864, he supported the movement of the Choshu clan.

sen.j: 忠能は長州藩を支持して変事を成功させることで、復帰を考えていたらしい。
sen.e: It seems that Tadayoshi aimed to come back to the political arena by a success of the incident with supporting the Choshu clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It seems that Tadayoshi aimed to come back to the political arena via the success of this affair in which he supported the Choshu clan.
It seems that Tadayoshi aimed to come back to the political arena via the success of this affair in which he supported the Choshu clan.

sen.j: が、禁門の変は結果的に失敗し、忠能は孝明天皇の怒りを買って処罰された。
sen.e: However, as a result, the Kinmon Incident failed and the Emperor Komei got angry and punished Tadayasu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the Kinmon Incident failed and as a result, the Emperor Komei got angry and punished Tadayasu.
However, the Kinmon Incident failed and as a result, the Emperor Komei got angry and punished Tadayasu.

sen.j: 慶応2年（1866年）、孝明天皇が崩御すると、復帰を許される。
sen.e: After the Emperor Komei died in 1866, he was allowed to come back.
After the Emperor Komei died in 1866, he was allowed to come back.
After the Emperor Komei died in 1866, he was allowed to come back.

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年）、中御門経之・正親町三条実愛らと組み、征夷大将軍徳川慶喜追討の勅書である討幕の密勅を明治天皇から出させることにも尽力。
sen.e: He made efforts to have the Emperor Meiji issue the secret Imperial command of attacking the shogunate, which was an Imperial command to attack seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA in 1867 with Tsuneyuki NAKAMIKADO and Sanenaru OGIMACHISANJO.

He made efforts to have the Emperor Meiji issue the secret Imperial command of attacking the shogunate, which was an Imperial command to attack seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA in 1867 with Tsuneyuki NAKAMIKADO and Sanenaru OGIMACHISANJO.
sen.cmt: This is convoluted and hard to read; perhaps putting the names of the people he targeted earlier in the sentence would be enough.
sen.e: He made efforts to have the Emperor Meiji issue the secret Imperial command of attacking the shogunate, which was an Imperial command to attack seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA in 1867 with Tsuneyuki NAKAMIKADO and Sanenaru OGIMACHISANJO.

sen.j: その後も岩倉具視らと協力して王政復古の大号令を実現させ、小御所会議では司会を務めた。
sen.e: After that, he cooperated to realize the Decree (of 1867) for the Restoration of Imperial Rule with Tomomi IWAKURA and was in charge of the moderator at Kogosho Conference (the meeting held in the presence of the Emperor in the Kogosho Conference Room of Kyoto Imperial Palace at the night of December 9, 1867, when the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule was issued).

After that, he cooperated in creating the Decree (of 1867) for the Restoration of Imperial Rule with Tomomi IWAKURA and was in charge of moderating at the Kogosho Conference (the meeting held in the presence of the Emperor in the Kogosho Conference Room of Kyoto Imperial Palace at the night of December 9, 1867, when the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule was issued).

After that, he cooperated in creating the Decree (of 1867) for the Restoration of Imperial Rule with Tomomi IWAKURA and was in charge of moderating at the Kogosho Conference (the meeting held in the presence of the Emperor in the Kogosho Conference Room of Kyoto Imperial Palace at the night of December 9, 1867, when the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule was issued).

sen.j: 明治21年（1888年）、80歳で薨去。
sen.e: In 1888 he died at the age of 80.
In 1888 he died at the age of 80.
In 1888 he died at the age of 80.

sen.j: 薨去直前に大勲位菊花大綬章を受章した。
sen.e: He received Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum at the time of dying.
He received the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum at the time of his death.
He received the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum at the time of his death.

sen.j: 官職位階履歴

sen.j: ※日付は明治4年までは旧暦
sen.e: The dates until 1871 are according to old lunar calendar.
The dates until 1871 are according to the old lunar calendar.
The dates until 1871 are according to the old lunar calendar.

sen.j: 文化 (日本)7年（1809年）1月10日、従五位に叙位。
sen.e: On January 10, 1809, he was conferred to Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank).
On January 10, 1809, he was conferred to Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank).
On January 10, 1809, he was conferred to Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank).

sen.j: 文化9年（1811年）1月20日、従五位に昇叙。
sen.e: On January 20, 1811, he was promoted to Jugoi.
On January 20, 1811, he was promoted to Jugoi.
On January 20, 1811, he was promoted to Jugoi.

sen.j: 文化10年（1812年）2月7日、侍従に任官。
sen.e: On February 7, 1812, he was assigned to jiju (a chamberlain).
On February 7, 1812, he was assigned to jiju (a chamberlain).
On February 7, 1812, he was assigned to jiju (a chamberlain).

sen.j: 文化11年（1813年）1月27日、正五位に昇叙し、侍従如元。
sen.e: On January 27, 1813, he was promoted to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) and remained in the position of jiju.
On January 27, 1813, he was promoted to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) and remained in the position of jiju.
On January 27, 1813, he was promoted to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) and remained in the position of jiju.

sen.j: 阿波国を兼任。
sen.e: He was assigned to the provisional vice governor of the Awa Province at the same time.
He was assigned as the provisional vice governor of Awa Province at the same time.
He was assigned as the provisional vice governor of Awa Province at the same time.

sen.j: 3月7日、元服し、殿上人を聴される。
sen.e: On March 7, he reached the manhood and allowed to be tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace).
On March 7, he reached adulthood and was allowed to be tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace).
On March 7, he reached adulthood and was allowed to be tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace).

sen.j: 3月19日、従四位に昇叙し、侍従阿波権介如元。
sen.e: On March 19, he was promoted to Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) and remained in the positions of jiju and the provisional vice governor of the Awa Province.
On March 19, he was promoted to Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) and maintained his positions as jiju and provisional vice governor of Awa Province.
On March 19, he was promoted to Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) and maintained his positions as jiju and provisional vice governor of Awa Province.

sen.j: 1月5日、従四位に昇叙し、侍従阿波権介如元。
sen.e: On January 5, he was promoted to Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) and remained in the positions of jiju and the provisional vice governor of the Awa Province.
On January 5, he was promoted to Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) and remained in the positions of jiju and the provisional vice governor of Awa Province.

sen.j: 1月28日、阿波権介を去る。
sen.e: On January 28, he resigned the provisional vice governor of the Awa Province.
On January 28, he resigned as provisional vice governor of Awa Province.

sen.j: 文政3年（1820年）1月4日、正四位に昇叙し、侍従如元。
sen.e: On January 4, 1820, he was promoted to Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) and remained in the position of jiju.
On January 4, 1820, he was promoted to Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) and remained in the position of jiju.
On January 4, 1820, he was promoted to Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) and remained in the position of jiju.

sen.j: 文政4年（1821年）5月10日、近衛府に転任。
sen.e: On May 10, 1821, he was transferred to Konoefu (the Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards).
On May 10, 1821, he was transferred to Konoefu (the Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards).
On May 10, 1821, he was transferred to Konoefu (the Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards).

sen.j: 文政5年（1822年）4月3日、伊予国を兼任。
sen.e: On April 3, 1822, he was also assigned to the provisional vice governor of the Iyo Province at the same time.
On April 3, 1822, he was also assigned to the provisional vice governor of the Iyo Province at the same time.
On April 3, 1822, he was also assigned to the provisional vice governor of the Iyo Province at the same time.

sen.j: 文政7年（1824年）6月19日、近衛府に転任し、伊予権介如元。
sen.e: On June 19, 1824, he was transferred to Konoefu and remained in the position of the provisional vice governor of the Oyo Province.
On June 19, 1824, he was transferred to Konoefu and remained in the position of the provisional vice governor of the Oyo Province.
On June 19, 1824, he was transferred to Konoefu and remained in the position of the provisional vice governor of the Iyo Province.
sen.cmt: 「Oyo Province」を「Iyo Province」に修正しました。

sen.j: 皇太后宮職を兼任。
sen.e: He was also assigned to kotaigo gushiki (Imperial Household Agency employee assigned to the household of Queen Mother) at the same time.
He was also assigned to kotaigo gushiki (Imperial Household Agency employee assigned to the household of the Queen Mother) at the same time.
He was also assigned to kotaigo gushiki (Imperial Household Agency employee assigned to the household of the Queen Mother) at the same time.

sen.j: 文政13年（1830年）2月2日、伊予権介を去る。
sen.e: On February 2, 1830 he resigned the provisional vice governor of the Oyo Province.
On February 2, 1830 he resigned as provisional vice governor of Oyo Province.
On February 2, 1830 he resigned as provisional vice governor of Iyo Province.
sen.cmt: 「Oyo Province」を「Iyo Province」に修正しました。

sen.j: 天保2年（1831年）12月19日、内教坊を兼帯。
sen.e: On December 19, 1831, he was also assigned to Naikyobo (training center of imperial dancing girls) at the same time.
On December 19, 1831, he was also assigned to Naikyobo (training center of imperial dancing girls) at the same time.
On December 19, 1831, he was also assigned to Naikyobo (training center of imperial dancing girls) at the same time.

sen.j: 7月8日、蔵人頭を兼帯。
sen.e: On July 8, he was also assigned to Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) at the same time.
On July 8, he was also assigned to Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) at the same time.
On July 8, he was also assigned to Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) at the same time.

sen.j: 8月4日、禁色を聴される。
sen.e: On August 4, he was allowed to put on kinjiki (literally, "forbidden colors," seven colors traditionally reserved for the imperial family and nobility).
On August 4, he was allowed to put on kinjiki (literally, "forbidden colors," seven colors traditionally reserved for the imperial family and nobility).
On August 4, he was allowed to put on kinjiki (literally, "forbidden colors," seven colors traditionally reserved for the imperial family and nobility).

sen.j: 8月28日、正四位に昇叙し、蔵人頭近衛府皇太后宮職如元。
sen.e: On August 28, he was promoted to Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) and remained in the position of Kurodo no to Konoefu kotaigo gushiki.
On August 28, he was promoted to Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) and remained in the position of Kurodo no to Konoefu kotaigo gushiki.

sen.j: 天保11年（1840年）3月27日、参議に補任。
sen.e: On March 27, 1840, he was assigned to Sangi (councilor).
On March 27, 1840, he was assigned to Sangi (councilor).
On March 27, 1840, he was assigned to Sangi (councilor).

sen.j: 近衛府皇太后宮職如元。
sen.e: He remained in the position of Konoefu kotaigo gushiki.
He remained in the position of Konoefu kotaigo gushiki.
He remained in the position of Konoefu kotaigo gushiki.

sen.j: 閏1月22日、皇太后欣子（よしこ）内親王に女院（新清和院）宣下のため、皇太后宮職を止め、新清和院別当を兼帯。
sen.e: On leap January 22, since the Empress Dowager appointed the Imperial Princess Yoshiko to nyoin (a close female relative of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) (Shinseiwain), he resigned kotaigo gushiki and was assigned to Shinseiwain betto (steward) at the same time.

On January 22, since the Empress Dowager appointed the Imperial Princess Yoshiko to nyoin (a close female relative of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) (Shinseiwain), he resigned as kotaigo gushiki and was assigned to Shinseiwain betto (steward) at the same time.

On the 22nd of January, which was a leap month, since the Empress Dowager appointed the Imperial Princess Yoshiko to nyoin (a close female relative of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) (Shinseiwain), he resigned as kotaigo gushiki and was assigned to Shinseiwain betto (steward) at the same time.

sen.j: 2月4日、従三位に昇叙し、新清和院別当参議近衛府如元。
sen.e: On February 4, he was promoted to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) and remained in the position of Shinseiwain betto Sangi Konoefu.

sen.j: 天保14年（1843年）1月4日、正三位に昇叙し、新清和院別当参議右近衛権中将如元。
sen.e: On January 4, 1843, he was promoted to Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) and remained in the position of Shinseiwain betto Sangi Ukone no gon no chujo (Provisional Middle Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards).

sen.j: 弘化元年（1844年）12月22日、中納言に転任し、新清和院別当如元。
sen.e: On December 22, 1844, he was transferred to Chunagon and remained in the position of Shinseiwain betto.
On December 22, 1844, he was transferred to Chunagon and remained in the position of Shinseiwain betto.
On December 22, 1844, he was transferred to Chunagon and remained in the position of Shinseiwain betto.

sen.j: 弘化2年（1845年）2月18日、従二位に昇叙し、新清和院別当権中納言如元。
sen.e: On February 18, 1845, he was promoted to Junii (Junior Second Rank) and remained in the position of Shinseiwain betto Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor).
On February 18, 1845, he was promoted to Junii (Junior Second Rank) and remained in the position of Shinseiwain betto Gon Chunagon (Provisional Middle Counselor).

sen.j: 弘化3年（1846年）6月20日、新清和院崩御に伴い、同院別当を止む。
sen.e: On June 20, 1846, he resigned Shinseiwain betto in accordance with the death of Shinseiwain.
On June 20, 1846, he resigned as Shinseiwain betto in accordance with the death of Shinseiwain.

sen.j: 3月14日、皇太后（仁孝天皇女御鷹司祺子＝やすこ）権大夫を兼任。
sen.e: On March 14, he was also assigned to kotaigo (Empress Dowager) (Yasuko TAKATSUKASA, nyogo (a high-ranking lady in the court of the Emperor Ninko) Gon no daibu (provisional master) at the same time.

sen.j: 5月27日、正二位に昇叙し、権中納言皇太后宮権大夫如元。
sen.e: On May 27, he was promoted to Shonii (Senior Second Rank) and remained in the position of Gon Chunagon kotaigogu Gon no daibu.
On May 27, he was promoted to Shonii (Senior Second Rank) and remained in the position of Gon Chunagon Kotaigogu Gon no daibu.
On May 27, he was promoted to Shonii (Senior Second Rank) and remained in the position of Gon Chunagon Kotaigogu Gon no daibu.

sen.j: 10月13日、皇太后崩御に付き、同権大夫を止む。
sen.e: On October 13, he resigned kotaigogu Gon no daibu in accordance with the death of the Empress Dowager.
On October 13, he resigned as Kotaigogu Gon no daibu in accordance with the death of the Empress Dowager.
On October 13, he resigned as Kotaigogu Gon no daibu in accordance with the death of the Empress Dowager.

sen.j: 12月27日、大納言に昇叙。
sen.e: On December 27, he was promoted to Dainagon.
On December 27, he was promoted to Dainagon.
On December 27, he was promoted to Dainagon.

sen.j: 安政5年（1858年）5月10日、議奏を兼帯。
sen.e: On May 10, 1858, he was assigned to giso at the same time.
On May 10, 1858, he was assigned to giso at the same time.
On May 10, 1858, he was assigned to giso at the same time.

sen.j: 文久2年（1862年）12月9日、朝廷の国事御用掛を兼帯。
sen.e: On December 9, 1862, he was assigned to Kokuji goyogakari (a general official of the Imperial Household in charge of the State affair) of the Imperial Court.
On December 9, 1862, he was assigned to Kokuji goyogakari (a general official of the Imperial Household in charge of State affairs) of the Imperial Court.
On December 9, 1862, he was assigned to Kokuji goyogakari (a general official of the Imperial Household in charge of State affairs) of the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 1月27日、議奏を解く。
sen.e: On January 27, he was removed from giso.
On January 27, he was removed as giso.
On January 27, he was removed as giso.

sen.j: 2月14日、大納言を辞任。
sen.e: On February he resigned Dainagon.
On February he resigned as Dainagon.
On February he resigned as Dainagon.

sen.j: 9月27日、本座を聴される。
sen.e: On September 27, he was allowed honza (the same position as the previous status).
On September 27, he was allowed honza (the same position as the previous status).
On September 27, he was allowed honza (the same position as the previous status).

sen.j: 12月9日、国事御用掛の廃止に伴い、朝廷の議定に異動。
sen.e: On December 9, he was transferred to gijo of the Imperial Court in accordance with the abolishment of Kokuji goyogakari.
On December 9, he was transferred to gijo of the Imperial Court in accordance with the abolishment of Kokuji goyogakari.
On December 9, he was transferred to gijo of the Imperial Court in accordance with the abolishment of Kokuji goyogakari.

sen.j: 1月17日、明治政府（この年に限って政府を伏す）神祇官を兼帯。
sen.e: On January 17, he was assigned to Jingikan (department of worship) of the Meiji government.
sen.cmt: 「この年に限って政府を伏す」の意味が不明です。
sen.e: On January 17, he was assigned to Jingikan (department of worship) of the Meiji government.
On January 17, he was assigned to Jingikan (department of worship) of the Meiji government (この年に限って政府を伏す).
sen.cmt: 「この年に限って政府を伏す」は「意味解釈が困難なため訳出できず」

sen.j: 2月3日、政府神祇事務総督から、政府輔弼に異動。
sen.e: On February 3, he was transferred to hohitsu (to make advices to the Emperor with full responsibility of the results) of the government from the ministerial governor of Jingi.
On February 3, he was transferred to hohitsu (to advise the Emperor with full responsibility for the results) of the government from the ministerial governor of Jingi.
On February 3, he was transferred to hohitsu (to advise the Emperor with full responsibility for the results) of the government from the ministerial governor of Jingi.

sen.j: 議定如元。
sen.e: He remained in the position of gijo.
He remained in the position of gijo.
He remained in the position of gijo.

sen.j: 閏4月20日、政府輔弼を辞す。
sen.e: On leap April 20, he resigned hohitsu of the government.
On April 20, he resigned as hohitsu of the government.
sen.cmt: Wording. Not sure why "leap" April 20 was there…
sen.e: On the 20th of April, which was a leap month, he resigned as hohitsu of the government.

sen.j: 閏4月21日、政府議定から官制改正により、議政官たる上局議定に異動。
sen.e: On leap April 21, he was transferred to Jokyoku Gijo (government service of Jokyoku law-making organ) which was Giseikan (Legislature) from gijo of the government by a reform of bureaucratic system.
On April 21, he was transferred to Jokyoku Gijo (government service of Jokyoku law-making organ) which was Giseikan (Legislature) from gijo of the government by a reform of the bureaucratic system.

On the 21st of April, he was transferred to Jokyoku Gijo (government service of Jokyoku law-making organ) which was Giseikan (Legislature) from gijo of the government by a reform of the bureaucratic system.
sen.cmt: 閏月は前列にすでに記述しているためここでは省きました。

sen.j: 閏4月26日、従一位に昇叙し、准大臣に補任。
sen.e: On leap April 26, he was promoted to Juichii (Junior First Rank) and was assigned to Jun-daijin (Vice Minister).
On April 26, he was promoted to Juichii (Junior First Rank) and was assigned to Jun-daijin (Vice Minister).
On the 26th of April, he was promoted to Juichii (Junior First Rank) and was assigned to Jun-daijin (Vice Minister).
sen.cmt: 閏月は前列にすでに記述しているためここでは省きました。

sen.j: 上局議定如元。
sen.e: He remained in the position of Jyokyoku Giso.
He remained in the position of Jyokyoku Giso.
He remained in the position of Jyokyoku Giso.

sen.j: 5月15日、上局議定から神祇官知事に異動。
sen.e: On May 15, he was transferred to the governor of Jingikan from Jyokyoku Giso.
On May 15, he was transferred to the governor of Jingikan from Jyokyoku Giso.
On May 15, he was transferred to the governor of Jingikan from Jyokyoku Giso.

sen.j: 7月8日、官制改正により、神祇官知事から神祇伯に異動し、宣教長官を兼帯。
sen.e: On July 8, he was transferred to Jingi haku (a chief official in charge of matters relating to Shintoism) from the governor of Jingikan and assigned to Senkyo Chokan (a chief of missionary work) a the same time by a reform of bureaucratic system.

On July 8, he was transferred to Jingi haku (a chief official in charge of matters relating to Shintoism) from the governor of Jingikan and assigned to Senkyo Chokan (a chief of missionary work) a the same time by a reform of the bureaucratic system.

On July 8, he was transferred to Jingi haku (a chief official in charge of matters relating to Shintoism) from the governor of Jingikan and assigned to Senkyo Chokan (a chief of missionary work) a the same time by a reform of the bureaucratic system.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）6月25日、神祇伯宣教長官をともに辞し、麝香間祗候と就る。
sen.e: On June 25, 1871, he resigned both Jingi haku and Senkyo Chokan, and was assigned to Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in Jako room).
On June 25, 1871, he resigned as both Jingi haku and Senkyo Chokan, and was assigned to Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in Jako room).
On June 25, 1871, he resigned as both Jingi haku and Senkyo Chokan, and was assigned to Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in Jako room).

sen.j: 明治13年（1880年）11月2日、勲一等旭日大綬章を受勲受章。
sen.e: On November 2, 1880, he received Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun.
On November 2, 1880, he received the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun.
On November 2, 1880, he received the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun.

sen.j: 明治17年（1884年）7月7日、侯爵を受爵。
sen.e: On July 7, 1884, he was conferred to marquis.
On July 7, 1884, he was conferred to marquis.
On July 7, 1884, he was conferred to marquis.

sen.j: 明治21年（1888年）5月14日、大勲位菊花大綬章を受勲受章。
sen.e: On May 14, 1888, he received Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum.
On May 14, 1888, he received the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum.
On May 14, 1888, he received the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum.
sen.cmt: ピリオドの前の余分なスペースの削除。

sen.j: 墓所
sen.e: Graveyard
Graveyard
Graveyard

sen.j: 東京都文京区の豊島岡墓地。
sen.e: Toshimagaoka Cemetery in Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo.
Toshimagaoka Cemetery in Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo.
Toshimagaoka Cemetery in Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo.

sen.j: 著作
sen.e: Literary works
Literary works
Literary works

sen.j: 『中山忠能日記』（原題は『正心誠意』）全3巻
sen.e: "Diary of Tadayasu NAKAYAMA" (original title was "Seishin Seii" [all sincerity]) consisting of three volumes.
"Diary of Tadayasu NAKAYAMA" (original title was "Seishin Seii" [all sincerity]), consisting of three volumes.
